description: Non-clinical, skills-first psychological interventions and micro-skills Marion can apply safely: behavior change, motivation, habit design, communication, emotion regulation, stress management, problem solving, and interpersonal repair. NOT therapy; no diagnosis; no treatment plans.

skills.name: Implementation Intentions (If–Then Planning)
skills.oneLiner: Pre-decide a trigger and a response so action happens automatically under real-world friction.
coreSteps: Choose a tiny response that’s unquestionably doable.
Write it as: If X happens, then I will do Y.
Rehearse once; adjust if it fails in reality.
actionablePrinciples: Make the cue observable (e.g., 'after coffee', not 'when I feel ready').
Make the response small (2 minutes) to beat avoidance.
Treat failure as signal to shrink the step or sharpen the cue.

faceExamples.title: Starting the task you avoid
faceExamples.scenario: User procrastinates on a big deliverable.
faceExamples.application: If it’s 9:00 and I open my laptop, then I write 3 ugly bullet points.

intentSignals: how do I make myself do it

skills.name: Habit Loop Design (Cue → Routine → Reward)
skills.oneLiner: Habits stick when the cue is consistent, the routine is easy, and the reward is immediate.
coreSteps: Identify the cue (time, place, emotion, preceding action).
Attach a reward (immediate satisfaction or relief).
Reduce friction for the good habit; increase friction for the competing habit.
actionablePrinciples: Environment beats willpower; redesign the environment.
Stack onto an existing habit (after X, do Y).
Use immediate rewards—future benefits don’t reinforce behavior well.

faceExamples.title: Daily training consistency
faceExamples.scenario: User wants to train but skips days.
faceExamples.application: After brushing teeth, do 10 minutes; then enjoy a favorite playlist.

intentSignals: how do I build a habit

skills.name: Motivational Interviewing Micro-Skills (OARS-lite)
skills.oneLiner: Elicit a person’s own reasons for change with reflections and choice, not lectures.
coreSteps: Reflect back the core meaning (one sentence).
Summarize and ask for the next step.
actionablePrinciples: Don’t argue the case for change harder than the user does.
Elicit 'change talk': reasons, desire, ability, need.
Offer a menu of options when resistance rises.

faceExamples.title: User is stuck and resistant
faceExamples.scenario: User says they 'should' change but won’t act.
faceExamples.application: What matters most if this *did* change? What’s one tiny step you’d accept?

intentSignals: I want to but I don’t

skills.name: Cognitive Reframing (CBT-style, Non-clinical)
skills.oneLiner: Stressful feelings often follow interpretations; test the interpretation and generate a more useful one.
coreSteps: Test the thought: evidence for/against; alternative explanations.
Choose a more balanced, workable thought; pick one action.
actionablePrinciples: Separate facts from stories.
Replace absolutist language (always/never) with precise language.
Don’t force positivity—aim for accuracy and usefulness.

faceExamples.title: Catastrophizing a setback
faceExamples.scenario: User thinks one failure means everything is doomed.
faceExamples.application: Alternative: 'This is a setback, not a verdict. Next best step is X.'

skills.name: Affect Labeling (Name It to Tame It)
skills.oneLiner: Briefly naming the emotion reduces intensity and improves self-control.
coreSteps: Name the need (safety, respect, clarity, rest).
Proceed with one small regulated action.
actionablePrinciples: Use precise labels (irritated vs furious) to reduce overwhelm.
Don’t over-explain—labeling works best short.
Pair with breathing or grounding for faster downshift.

faceExamples.title: Anger spike in a conversation
faceExamples.scenario: User is about to snap at someone.
faceExamples.application: ‘I’m feeling threatened and disrespected’ → pause → ask one clarifying question.

skills.name: Box Breathing (4-4-4-4)
skills.oneLiner: A simple breath pattern to reduce arousal and restore executive control.
actionablePrinciples: Use when intensity is 6/10 or higher.
Pair with a micro-commitment after (one small next action).
If dizziness occurs, shorten counts and breathe normally.

faceExamples.title: Pre-meeting anxiety
faceExamples.scenario: User is anxious before a call.
faceExamples.application: 3 rounds, then write the first sentence you’ll say.

skills.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
skills.oneLiner: Shift attention to immediate sensory data to interrupt spirals and rumination.
actionablePrinciples: Best when intrusive thoughts loop.
Keep it fast: 60–90 seconds.
Then choose one controllable next step.

faceExamples.title: Rumination loop
faceExamples.scenario: User can’t stop replaying a mistake.
faceExamples.application: Do 5-4-3-2-1, then write one repair message or one next action.

skills.name: Structured Problem Solving (Define → Options → Choose → Test)
skills.oneLiner: Reduce overwhelm by converting vague stress into a defined problem and a testable plan.
coreSteps: Define the problem in one sentence (facts).
Set a success criterion (what ‘better’ looks like).
Pick one option; define the smallest test.
actionablePrinciples: If stuck, shrink the test until it’s unavoidable.
Measure outcomes, not feelings alone.
Prefer reversible decisions when uncertain.

faceExamples.title: Too many moving parts
faceExamples.scenario: User is overwhelmed by a project.
faceExamples.application: Define the bottleneck; pick one 30-minute test; review.

intentSignals: I don’t know what to do

skills.name: Assertive Request Script (DEAR-lite)
skills.oneLiner: Ask clearly without aggression: describe, express, ask, and reinforce.
coreSteps: Reinforce: why it matters / shared benefit.
actionablePrinciples: Use specific behaviors and timelines.
Avoid mind-reading and global labels.
If they say no, ask for an alternative offer.

faceExamples.title: Negotiating a deadline
faceExamples.application: ‘When X slipped, I felt boxed in. Can you send Y by 3pm? It keeps us on track.’

skills.name: Repair After Conflict (Impact → Ownership → Change)
skills.oneLiner: Repair works when you name impact, take responsibility, and propose a concrete behavioral change.
coreSteps: Change: what you’ll do next time.
Invite: ask what they need to feel safe/clean.
actionablePrinciples: Don’t mix apology with defense in the same sentence.
Offer one concrete future behavior, not vague intent.
Ask one clarifying question and stop talking.

faceExamples.title: You snapped at someone
faceExamples.scenario: User regrets how they handled a moment.
faceExamples.application: ‘I raised my voice. That likely felt unsafe. I’ll pause next time and ask for 5 minutes.’

skills.name: Sleep Hygiene (Micro-Protocol)
skills.oneLiner: Better sleep improves mood and executive function; small changes beat perfect routines.
coreSteps: Cut caffeine 8 hours before bed (or reduce).
Brain-dump thoughts to paper; plan tomorrow in 3 bullets.
Cool, dark room; phone out of reach.
actionablePrinciples: Fix wake time first; bedtime follows.
If racing thoughts: write them, don’t fight them.
Treat sleep as performance infrastructure, not virtue.

faceExamples.title: Late-night overthinking
faceExamples.scenario: User can’t shut off their mind.
faceExamples.application: 3-bullet brain dump + 2 minutes of slow breathing.

microProtocols.name: 2-Minute Start Protocol
steps: Choose the smallest visible action (open doc, title it, write 1 bullet).
Stop at 2 minutes or continue if momentum appears.
If stopped, schedule the next 2-minute start.
microProtocols.safetyNotes: Non-clinical. If user expresses self-harm intent, switch to safety/containment guidance.

microProtocols.name: Conflict Pause → Reset
microProtocols.goal: Prevent escalation and preserve relationship repair.
steps: Ask for a short pause (5–20 minutes).
Return with one clear request and one listening question.
microProtocols.safetyNotes: If violence risk is present, prioritize de-escalation and safe exit.

applicationRules.instruction: Do not diagnose, label disorders, or prescribe treatment. Provide skills, education, and options.
If self-harm/violence/illegal intent is detected, shift to safety framing and high-level support; avoid operational details.
Offer choices and ask preference when uncertainty is high; avoid commanding tone unless user explicitly asks for direct instruction.
Prefer smallest testable step (2–10 minutes) over large plans when motivation is low or overload is high.

meta.intendedUse: Skills and interventions layer for Marion (psychology domain). Drives practical, non-clinical guidance and structured responses.
